title: GERMAN STRIKE SLOWING EUROPEAN AUTO OUTPUT
title_page: GERMAN STRIKE SLOWING EUROPEAN AUTO OUTPUT - The New York Times
maintext:
Opel, G.M.'s German unit, said a transmission plant near Vienna was forced to close today, and assembly of the Corsa, a front-wheel-drive subcompact car built at a factory in Saragossa, Spain, would be threatened early next month.
Assembly lines at three Opel factories in Germany and one in Antwerp, Belgium, have been stopped by the strike since May 22. An Opel official said the production shortfall was costing about $22 million a day.
Ford Turns to Other Plants
Officials at Ford Werke, Ford's West German unit, say the company has thus far been able to keep its German plants running by drawing on parts from its factories in other European countries. But officials said the auto maker would be forced by dwindling parts supplies to close plants in Germany and Belgium next Wednesday if the strike continued.
Volkswagen, Germany's biggest auto maker, said on Tuesday that it was closing six factories in Germany and one in Belgium, effective today, halting production of about 5,000 cars a day. Two factories of VW's Audi subsidiary in Germany have been shut down since May 18.
Evidently to play down the effects of the strike, a VW official said that most of the company's 110,000 workers had been sent on a one-week enforced vacation. But he acknowledged that only about half of the employees would resume work when plants reopen next Monday.
